title: Quiz 5: FQE June 2023
description: Full exam paper from June 2023 FQE covering MCQs, Short Answer Questions, and Clinical Scenarios.

questions.question: Which of the following is a component of the internal genitalia?
questions.explanation: The internal genitalia consist of the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, and vagina. The Mons pubis, Skene's glands, and Bartholin's glands are parts of the vulva (external genitalia).
questions.hint: Think about structures located inside the pelvic cavity versus visible externally.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning the blood supply of the external genitalia?

options.text: The main supply is from the branches of the internal pudendal artery
The main supply is from the branches of the femoral artery
The deep and dorsal arteries supply the labia majora
The veins drain into the external pudendal vein

questions.explanation: The internal pudendal artery is the primary blood supply to the perineum and external genitalia.
questions.hint: The artery shares its name with the nerve supplying the perineum.

questions.question: The following statement is true about the relations of the vagina:

options.text: The upper 1/3 is related with the pouch of Douglas posteriorly
The middle 1/3 is related with the anterior rectal wall posteriorly
The upper 1/3 is related with the urethra anteriorly
The lower 1/3 is related with the bulbocavernosus muscles laterally

questions.explanation: The posterior fornix of the vagina (upper 1/3) is covered by the peritoneum of the Rectouterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas), which is clinically important for culdocentesis.
questions.hint: This anatomical relation allows access to the peritoneal cavity through the vagina.

questions.question: Which statement is correct about the anterior posterior diameter of the fetal head during engagement?

options.text: Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter measures 9.5 cm, complete flexion with brow presentation
Mentovertical diameter measures 11 cm, partial extension with brow preservation
Occipitofrontal diameter measures 10 cm, marked deflexion with vertex presentation
Sub-occipitofrontal diameter measures 10 cm, incomplete flexion with vertex presentation

questions.explanation: Sub-occipitofrontal diameter (10 cm) presents when the head is incompletely flexed in vertex presentation. Suboccipito-bregmatic (9.5 cm) presents in full flexion.
questions.hint: Consider the diameter presented when the chin is not quite touching the chest.

questions.question: Concerning the diameters of the pelvic inlet, which one is correct?

options.text: Diagonal conjugate cannot be measured clinically

questions.explanation: The Diagonal Conjugate (~12.5 cm) extends from the sacral promontory to the lower border of the symphysis pubis and is the only inlet diameter that can be measured clinically.
questions.hint: This diameter is measured during a digital vaginal examination.

questions.question: Which of the following is an exclusive comprehensive (CeMOC) function?
questions.explanation: CeMOC facilities perform all BEmOC functions plus Caesarean Section and Blood Transfusion.
questions.hint: Requires a laboratory and cross-matching capability.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the menstrual cycle?

options.text: The luteal phase varies from cycle to cycle
The luteal phase is constant at 14 days
The follicular phase is constant at 14 days

questions.explanation: The luteal phase (secretory phase) is relatively constant at 14 days because it depends on the life span of the corpus luteum. Variations in cycle length are usually due to the follicular phase.
questions.hint: The second half of the cycle is fixed.

questions.question: Which statement is true concerning the Hypothalamo-Pituitary Ovarian hormones?

options.text: Luteinizing hormone stimulates proliferation of granulosa cells
Gonadotropin releasing hormone has a half-life of 15 minutes
Estrogens exerts a negative feedback effect on the release of Follicle Stimulating Hormone

questions.explanation: Rising estrogen levels from the developing follicle exert negative feedback on the pituitary to suppress FSH secretion, ensuring the selection of a dominant follicle.
questions.hint: How does the body stop recruiting more follicles once one is growing?

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with per vaginal bleeding. Which of the following can be performed to exclude the cause?
questions.explanation: A speculum examination allows direct visualization of the cervix and vagina to identify lesions (like cancer or polyps) or atrophy, which are key causes of post-menopausal bleeding.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a probable manifestation of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Chadwick's sign (bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina) is a probable sign of pregnancy observed by the examiner.
questions.hint: Think about color changes in the genital tract.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about physiological changes that take place in the respiratory system during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: The elevation of the diaphragm by the gravid uterus decreases the Residual Volume and Functional Residual Capacity. Tidal volume increases to meet oxygen demand.
questions.hint: The uterus pushes upwards, reducing resting lung space.

questions.question: Which of the following is a physiological action of estrogen in the female reproductive system?

options.text: Growth of axillary and pubic hair
Increases proliferation of the lobules of the breast
Causes hyperplasia of the cervix and increase cervical gland secretions

questions.explanation: Estrogen causes proliferation (hyperplasia) of reproductive tissues, increases vascularity, and stimulates cervical glands to produce copious mucus. (Note: Option D is a very specific estrogenic effect often contrasted with progesterone).

questions.question: Antenatal profiles are tests done during pregnancy. Which one of the following is an auxiliary test?
questions.explanation: Hb, Blood Group, and Urinalysis are considered core/basic tests. Hepatitis B, while standard, is sometimes classified as additional/auxiliary in resource-limited classifications compared to the absolute basics.
questions.hint: Which test might not be done in a very basic dispensary setting compared to Hb/Urine?

questions.question: Aisha (30y) has a 5-year-old child, lost a child at 2 years, had a miscarriage at 3 months, and is currently pregnant. What is her Parity?
questions.explanation: Parity counts deliveries after viability (28 weeks). 1st born (5y) + 2nd born (died at 2y) = Para 2. Miscarriage at 3 months = +1 abortion. Current pregnancy is not included in Parity yet. Result: Para 2 + 1.
questions.hint: Count the number of times she has delivered a viable baby.

questions.question: Aisha's LMP was 28/02/2023. Calculate her expected date of delivery (EDD) using the format DD/MM/YYYY.
questions.explanation: Feb 28 + 7 days = March 7. March - 3 months = December. Year 2023. Alternatively, 280 days from Feb 28 usually lands on Dec 5th.

questions.question: Identify a true statement regarding anaemia in pregnancy?

options.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency anaemia occurs in pregnancy
Nutritional anaemia is the common form
Can cause anaemia in the newborn

questions.explanation: Nutritional anaemia (specifically Iron Deficiency) is the most common cause due to increased demands.
questions.hint: Deficiency of a mineral found in diet.

questions.question: A 28-year-old at 33 weeks presents with painless heavy bright red bleeding, BP 90/60, Pulse 120. Immediate management?
questions.explanation: The patient has major Placenta Previa with shock (hemodynamic instability). Immediate delivery via C-section is required to save the mother's life.

questions.question: In management of diabetes in pregnancy:

options.text: Insulin therapy is mandatory during labour
Elective caesarian section of indicated in all patients
Serial ultrasound is recommended to monitor fetal growth
Patients are managed with oral hypoglycemic during the antenatal period

questions.explanation: Serial ultrasounds are crucial to monitor for macrosomia (excessive growth) or IUGR/polyhydramnios associated with diabetes.
questions.hint: Monitoring the baby's size is critical.

questions.question: During clinical pelvimetry, which feature indicates a contracted/inadequate pelvis?

options.text: Rounded pubic arch accommodating at least 2 fingers

questions.explanation: A sharp, 'beaked' forepelvis is characteristic of an Android (contracted/male-type) pelvis.
questions.hint: Look for the shape that is not round or wide.

questions.question: Determine a true statement concerning breech presentation:

options.text: Frank breech is commonly present in s multiparas
Complete breech is common in primigravida
The thighs and legs are fully extended in footling breech
The presenting part is the buttocks and external genitalia in frank breech

questions.explanation: In Frank Breech, the hips are flexed and knees extended, so the buttocks present.
questions.hint: Legs are up by the ears.

questions.question: Concerning hyperemesis gravidarum, which of the following is correct?

options.text: Serum electrolytes reveals high levels of potassium
Multiple gestation is a risk factor

questions.explanation: Multiple gestation increases HCG levels, which is a key driver of hyperemesis. Urinalysis shows ketones (starvation), not protein.

questions.question: Which of the following is an ulcer forming sexually transmitted infection?
questions.explanation: Primary Syphilis presents with a chancre (ulcer).

questions.question: Julia presents with foul smelling discharge and lower abdominal pain. Impression: PID. Which statement is true?

options.text: Can be treated with 5-day course and doxycycline
Ultrasound reveals a beaded string tubal wall
Laparotomy is indicated in acute disease

questions.explanation: Neisseria gonorrhoea and Chlamydia trachomatis are the primary causative agents of PID.

questions.question: In elimination of mother to child transmission of HIV which of the following is a guideline in women admitted to labour and delivery units?
questions.explanation: Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) should be avoided to keep the amniotic sac intact as a barrier against viral transmission for as long as possible.

questions.question: In pre-labour premature rupture of membranes at 32 weeks, identify the appropriate management:
questions.explanation: At 32 weeks (preterm), conservative management (antibiotics, steroids, monitoring) is preferred to prolong pregnancy and allow lung maturity, provided there is no infection.
questions.hint: Try to keep the baby inside a bit longer.

questions.question: Arrange the mechanisms of labour in vertex presentation in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: The standard sequence is Engagement -> Descent -> Flexion -> Internal Rotation -> Extension -> Restitution/External Rotation -> Expulsion.
questions.hint: Every Darn Fool In Egypt Eats Raw Eggs.

questions.question: Chebet, primigravida at 8 weeks gestation, presents with fever and chills after travel to Kisumu. Blood slide positive for malaria. What is the definitive treatment?
questions.explanation: In the FIRST trimester (8 weeks), Oral Quinine is the drug of choice for uncomplicated malaria. AL is typically reserved for 2nd and 3rd trimesters in many guidelines (though WHO now allows AL in 1st trimester, Quinine remains the classic exam answer for 1st trimester safety).

questions.question: Which statement is true concerning sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)?

options.text: Bacterial vaginosis presents with fishy vaginal discharge
Trichomonas vaginalis presents with curd like whitish discharge
Congenital syphilis is associated with oligohydramnios
Lymphogranuloma venerium is caused by chlamydia granulomatis

questions.explanation: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray-white discharge with a fishy odor (positive Whiff test).

questions.question: Which of the following is a fetal indication for induction of labour?
questions.explanation: IUFD is a clear indication for induction to expel the fetus. Acute fetal distress (A) is usually an indication for C-section, not induction (which takes time).

questions.question: Regarding rhesus incompatibility management, which of the following is true?

options.text: Direct coombs test is done antenatally
Indirect coombs test is done on cord blood
Blood group and indirect coombs test are done in the first visit at 28 weeks and at 35 weeks
Anti D is administered only after delivery

questions.explanation: Screening (Indirect Coombs) is done at booking, 28 weeks, and 34-36 weeks to detect sensitization. Anti-D is given at 28 weeks (prophylaxis) AND after delivery.

questions.question: According to Medical Eligibility Criteria, who should NOT use combined oral contraceptives?

options.text: Women with history of blood clotting disorders
Women with no history of hypertension
Women with asymptomatic gall bladder disease

questions.explanation: History of blood clotting disorders (DVT/PE) is a Category 4 (Absolute Contraindication) for COCs due to estrogen's pro-thrombotic effect.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding deep venous thrombosis in pregnancy?

options.text: Heparin should be given subcutaneous in acute phase
Backers cyst is not a differential diagnosis
Depo provera is a risk factor
Warfarin is contraindicated in the first trimester and after 36 weeks

questions.explanation: LMWH (Heparin) is the anticoagulant of choice in pregnancy. Warfarin is contraindicated in 1st trimester but NOT necessarily after 36 weeks (though often switched for delivery management, stating it's 'contraindicated after 36 weeks' is less accurate than the Heparin statement).
questions.hint: Heparin does not cross the placenta.

questions.question: Which of the following statement is true regarding cancer of the cervix?

options.text: It is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 infection
It takes 5 years for women with pre-cancer lesions to develop cancer
The lifetime risk of acquiring human papilloma virus in sexually active women is 86% by age 50
Condoms are protective against human papilloma virus

questions.explanation: HPV is extremely common; lifetime risk is high. Condoms offer some protection but not complete (skin-to-skin). Progression usually takes >10 years. Type 16/18 cause cancer, type 6 causes warts.

questions.question: Regarding treatment of cancer of the cervix:

options.text: Radiation therapy can be used in all stages
Stage III can be managed using surgery
Adenocarcinoma is best treated with radiotherapy

questions.explanation: Radiotherapy can be used in all stages, either as primary treatment or adjuvant. Surgery is limited to early stages.

questions.question: A 30 year old presents with a polycystic ovarian syndrome. Identify a characteristic of this disease.
questions.explanation: Hyperandrogenism (clinical or biochemical) is a key diagnostic criterion for PCOS (Rotterdam criteria). Oligomenorrhea (D) is also a feature, but Hyperandrogenism is the underlying hormonal hallmark listed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary?
questions.explanation: Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor. Fibroma and Brenner are epithelial/stromal and usually benign.

questions.question: A 40-year-old nulliparous woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding for more than 6 months. The following is likely?

options.text: She is likely to have cancer of the cervix

questions.explanation: Heavy bleeding and nulliparity at 40 suggest symptomatic fibroids (or endometrial cancer, but fibroids are very common causes of HMB). Symptomatic because she is bleeding.

questions.question: In grading of pelvic organ prolapse grading. Which one is NOT correctly matched.

options.text: Grade I – Leading edge of the prolapse remains 1 cm or more above the hymen
Grade II – leading edge of prolapse extends from 1 cm above to the level of the hymen
Grade III – Leading edge of prolapse extends beyond hymen but without complete vaginal eversion
Grade IV – Complete eversion of the vagina

questions.explanation: Grade II is defined as the leading edge being between 1 cm above and 1 cm below the hymen (not just 'to the level'). The phrasing in B is slightly off or imprecise compared to standard POP-Q.

questions.question: Regarding endometrial carcinoma, which statement is correct?

options.text: Occurs in women with a mean age of 60 years
Prognosis is poor regardless of the stage
Is associated with progesterone effects on the endometrium

questions.explanation: It is mainly Adenocarcinoma (not Squamous). It is a disease of post-menopausal women (mean age ~60). Prognosis is good if caught early. It is associated with ESTROGEN, not progesterone.

questions.question: During resuscitation, you establish there is no chest movement. The best action to take is;

options.text: Do cardiopulmonary resuscitation at 3 chest compressions to one breath
Put up oxygen via nasal prong at one litre per minute

questions.explanation: If the baby is not breathing (no chest movement), the priority is ventilation. 40-60 breaths/min is the standard rate for neonatal resuscitation. Compressions are only started if HR remains low despite ventilation.
questions.hint: Ventilation is the most important step.

questions.question: Mary, Para 1+0 gravida 2 at 30 weeks gestation presents with lower abdominal pains and blood mucoid discharge. Cervix 2cm. Outline plan of management: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Preterm labor management: Admission, Steroids for lung maturity, Tocolysis to delay delivery, Neuroprotection.

questions.question: Fatuma, 30-year-old at 33 weeks, presents with severe headache, epigastric pain, BP 160/118. Describe principles of management: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Severe Pre-eclampsia management: Seizure prophylaxis, BP control, Fluid balance, Delivery.

questions.question: Describe how you will actively manage third stage of labour (AMTSL):
questions.explanation: Sequence: Rule out twin -> Drug -> Traction -> Massage.

questions.question: Jane presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. How will you evaluate her to make a diagnosis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Evaluation involves history, physical exam, imaging (US), and labs (CBC, hormonal).

questions.question: You perform Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA). Outline the indications for complete evacuation: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Signs of empty uterus: Gritty sensation, red foam, uterine contraction around cannula.

questions.question: Describe the components of the APGAR scoring system: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: A-P-G-A-R: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration.

questions.question: Regarding adolescent sexual health, describe risks associated with early initiation of sexual activities: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risks: Pregnancy, STIs, Cancer (HPV), Trauma, School dropout.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with severe lower abdominal pain, radiating to shoulder, amenorrhea 8 weeks, positive pregnancy test, BP 90/60. What relevant investigation will you order to confirm diagnosis?

richContent.content: Clinical Scenario: 32-year-old female, acute abdomen, shock, amenorrhea 8 weeks.

questions.explanation: Pelvic ultrasound (to identify adnexal mass/free fluid) is the confirmatory test for Ectopic Pregnancy. Culdocentesis is an alternative if US is unavailable.

questions.question: A married couple presents with failure to conceive after 8 years. Describe your approach on how to evaluate this couple: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Take detailed history from BOTH partners
Perform physical examination on BOTH partners
Order Seminal Fluid Analysis for the male
Check tubal patency (HSG) for the female
Assume it is the female's fault

questions.explanation: Evaluation involves: History/Exam of both, Male (Semen Analysis), Female (Ovulation, Tubes, Uterus).
